original_text:
**INSTITUTION
TRAUMA
DISCHARGE SUMMARY
PATIENT NAME :
**NAME[AAA , BBB M]
ACCOUNT # :
**ID-NUM
**ROOM
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN :
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ]
ADMISSION DATE :
**DATE[Nov 19 2007]
DISCHARGE DATE :
**DATE[Jan 12 2008]
DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS( ES ):
1. Cholecystitis .
2. Pancreatitis .
3. Superior mesenteric artery aneurysm repair .
4. Duodenal stricture .
SERVICE :
Surgery .
ATTENDING :
Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] .
PROCEDURES :
1. **DATE[Nov 19 2007] - Superior mesenteric artery aneurysm repair with PTFE graft and reimplantation of branches .
2. **DATE[Nov 20 2007] - Exploratory laparotomy with gastropexy .
3. **DATE[Dec 16 2007] - Exploratory laparotomy with drainage of abscess .
Placement of JG tube and fascia closure .
**INSTITUTION COURSE :
This is a **AGE[in 40s]-year-old male who back in **DATE[Jun 2007] presented with severe biliary pancreatitis and a ruptured gallbladder .
At this time , a percutaneous cholecystotomy tube was placed and currently at this time is still in place .
As a complication , he developed multiorgan failure and has quite a tenuous course over the past few months .
The patient subsequently developed a SMA aneurysm that required a graft repair on **DATE[Nov
19 2007] .
He did have an upper GI with small-bowel followthrough .
On **DATE[Nov 31 2007] , it showed narrowing at the D2 level of duodenum .
Subsequently , his stay was then complicated with respiratory failure , ARDS , sepsis for which he spent some time in the Intensive Care Unit .
In the beginning of **DATE[Jan 2008] , the patient was transferred out of the ICU to the monitored floor .
Since then , his stay has been relatively unremarkable and appeared to be improving daily .
Neurologically :
This patient does have a history of schizoaffective disorder , and on the floor , his affect has been relatively stable on the medications bupropion and olanzapine .
Cardiovascular :
High blood pressure that is maintained with metoprolol b.i.d. 100 mg .
Pulmonary wise :
Over the past week , his oxygen saturation has ranged between 95% and 100% without any supplemental oxygen .
GI wise :
He has been receiving tube feeds of Jevity at 40 mL per hour .
Plan is to advance his tube feeds to 45 , then up to 65 slowly as much as the patient can tolerate .
As the patient does have duodenal strictures , the patient has been kept on a clear only diet including JELL-O and soup .
Hematologically :
His hemoglobin and hematocrit have been stable .
Infectious Disease :
Recently , the patient had complaint of urinary tract symptoms including discomfort on urination .
He had a urine culture that did not grow any bacteria .
However , it did grown yeast and he will be discharged with Diflucan .
Genitourinary :
On **DATE[Jan 12 2008] , Urology did change it to suprapubic catheter .
This catheter had been placed originally because the patient at one point during his stay had pulled the full catheter through his urethra damaging .
Recently , the patient stated that he has been able to urinate through his penis as normal .
Prophylaxis :
The patient is on heparin subcutaneous 5000 units as well as Pepcid .
Drains :
The patient has a right PTC that drains bile , a GJ tube on the left side .
Medications should only be put through the G-tube and never through the J-tube .
Tube feeds are to be given through the J-tube .
Wounds :
The patient has a midline incision from prior surgery which at the time of discharge had been healing well .
DISCHARGE CONDITION :
Stable .
DISPOSITION :
Discharged to the Transitional Care Unit at Montefiore .
MEDICATIONS :
1. Aspirin 81 mg .
2. __________ application topically .
3. Bupropion 100 mg through G-tube t.i.d.
4. __________ 20 mg G-tube b.i.d.
5. Heparin subcutaneous 5000 units every 12 hours .
6. He is on a monitored scale of regular insulin .
7. Metoprolol 100 mg G-tube b.i.d.
8. Mirtazapine 15 mg G-tube nightly .
9. Olanzapine 20 mg G-tube nightly .
10. Hydromorphone 2 mg G-tube q.2 hours p.r.n. for pain .
11. Senna 10 mL G-tube daily p.r.n. for constipation .
12. Diflucan 150 mg G-tube daily x 3 days .
13. Dulcolax suppository 10 mg per rectum daily p.r.n. for constipation .
14. Milk of magnesia 30 mL G-tube p.r.n. for constipation .
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS :
The patient will be set up to work with physical therapist and occupational therapist .
He is to be out of bed and ambulating as tolerated with assistance .
Around **DATE[Feb 16 2008] , the patient is to have a PTC catheter study to assess for biliary leak .
He is also to have an upper GI study through the G-tube to evaluate the duodenal stricture .
Scripts for these studies were written for the patient .
___________________________
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ]
Dictator :
**NAME[WWW XXX] , M.D.
AL/vm
D : **DATE[Jan 12 2008] 20:04:51
T : **DATE[Jan 12 2008] 22:34:55
R : **DATE[Jan 14 2008] 06:08:51/sg
Job ID :
424561 /**ID-NUM
Cc:
*** Dictated By : -**NAME[XXX , SSS] ***
Electronically Signed by **NAME[YYY ZZZ]
**DATE[Jan 15 2008] 09:25:37 AM
